text: My team is planning our next hires and we're looking to grow our creative team as we mostly outsource our design and are really lacking in infographics, video, etc. that we think can level up our content. Would love to hear folks experiences with hiring someone with graphic design expertise that acts as an in-house agency type role with other content marketers making requests for projects vs. a person who is a content marketer with a multimedia lens (aka they are brainstorming the content, topics, etc. but making videos, visuals, decks)

text: also your success hiring for specialists (i.e. just video versus a multimedia/creative generalist) and the typical career level you've had success with

text:
my 2 cents:

we just stormed on this problem for 5 months. my experience has been, if i had to do it again: hire senior first.

it’s critical someone models behavior, owns the overall vision, and defines how to grow the department. it also delegates much of the identification, interviewing and onboarding of designers to an SME.

we struggled with swapping in juniors for a while. they didn’t have a single source of truth to design against, it limited accountability (how long does an infographic take vs a stylized chart vs meta image for social), and the lack of experience led to a lot of delays or missed work. a senior person would have either done it before or had the experience to say “look at what competitors are doing” or “google it”

text:
<@U010GTFAFK9> absolutely.

I've seen so many situations where there's a clear issue with no one on the client's side who owns the creative vision. Instead, the responsibility is diffused to other decision makers who have ZILCHO skill in communicating with creatives, so even their in-house teams develop the dreaded bad-client/frustrated-designer relationships.

Or, the responsibility is farmed out to a third party, who's given an execution budget of like $2k /month and expected to bear the burden of a creative director. Good luck getting senior-level creative control for $24,000/year!
